thread.title: Twitter dips under IPO price amid struggles to define social network
thread.title_full: Twitter dips under IPO price amid struggles to define social network - MarketWatch

author: Caitlin Huston
title: Twitter dips under IPO price amid struggles to define social network
text:
Bloomberg Co-founder Jack Dorsey is serving as interim chief executive of Twitter Inc. as the company searches for a permanent CEO. Struggling Twitter Inc. reached a new nadir Thursday, trading below its initial offering price for the first time.
Twitter shares fell 6% in intraday trading Thursday, selling as low as $25.92. The move comes on a tough day for technology stocks, but also a difficult time for Twitter TWTR, -5.83% as it looks for a new chief executive and struggles to clarify its platform.
Twitter beat its second-quarter profit expectations last month but reported a weak growth rate at 12% year-over-year. Then, on its earnings call, Twitter executives appeared downbeat, calling the growth rate “unacceptable” while discussing a simplification of the platform that could include moving away from the real-time stream for which Twitter is known.
Twitter has started rolling out new features, including the recent deployment of direct messages with unlimited characters and a two-year partnership with the National Football League . On Thursday, Twitter expanded its mobile advertising network , part of a push that has succeeded in pushing revenues higher at a rapid rate.
Investors are also waiting on a new chief executive announcement after former CEO Dick Costolo stepped down July 1. Jack Dorsey, a Twitter co-founder and chief executive of Square, has taken on the role on an interim basis.
Twitter went public in November 2013 and had a record close of $73.31 on Dec. 26, 2013. Shares have fallen 27% in the last month and 29% in the last three months.
Other social-media stocks also struggled Thursday: Shares of Facebook Inc. FB, -4.98% fell 4%, and shares of LinkedIn Corp. LNKD, -4.31% declined 3%. Media stocks also took a hit Thursday as The Walt Disney Co. DIS, -6.04% and Time Warner Inc. TWC, -2.02% were downgraded and others in the sector face an uncertain entertainment climate.
The Nasdaq Composite, which encompasses many technology stocks, fell 2% Thursday to $4898.70.
